Award.AwardTitle: Ergodic Theory of Nonamenable Group Actions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Classical dynamics studies how systems change in time. Ergodic theory focuses on the statistical behavior of dynamical systems. Applications of ergodic theory are widespread: from traffic modelling to aerospace engineering and population dynamics. It is natural and of practical importance to generalize the role of time in a dynamical system to more complicated groups of symmetries. This generalized notion of dynamics leads to applications in statistical mechanics, number theory, and geometry. However, new tools are needed, especially in the particular case when the group of symmetries is non nonamenable, which means that boundary phenomena are too significant to be safely ignored (unlike intervals in the integers or real numbers). Nonamenable groups naturally arise in many parts of mathematics, such as geometry and number theory. This project is concerned with developing the tools needed to analyze the ergodic theory of nonamenable group actions.

There are five specific goals. The first is to continue developing sofic entropy theory. This is a vast generalization of Kolmogorov-Sinai entropy to actions of sofic groups, a class of groups that contains all amenable groups and residually finite groups. One major aim of this research is to determine to what extent Ornstein theory can be extended beyond actions of amenable groups. The second goal is to establish pointwise ergodic theorems for geometrically defined groups (e.g. Lie groups, CAT(0) cubulated groups, relatively hyperbolic groups) using techniques recently discovered by the PI and Amos Nevo. The third goal is to import tools from geometric group theory into the study of measured equivalence relations. The fourth goal is to continue to analyzing the structure of the space of weak equivalence classes of actions of a given group. This space serves as a classifying object for the ways in which the Rokhlin Lemma fails for nonamenable groups. Because the Rokhlin Lemma is of crucial importance in Ornstein theory, this topic is intimately connected with the first goal. The fifth goal is to continue clarifying what the space of stationary actions of a given group "looks like.'' One major focus is on new constructions of stationary actions (via invariant random subgroups or measured equivalence relations). Another is on generic behavior of stationary actions. Yet another is to apply the new techniques to the study of harmonic functions and random walks; topics deeply connected with stationary actions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Classical dynamics studies systems that evolve in time with a focus on the long term behavior. The theory has been expanded by replacing the notion of time with a group of symmetries. In this set-up, one has a phase space which may be thought of as the space of all possible configurations of a system. Classically, the evolution of time provides a transformation on this space and the focus of the theory is on long-term behavior. One can generalize this set-up by replacing the single transformation with a group of transformations. 

 

For example, if time is replaced by the symmetries of 3-dimensional real space, then the resulting theory may be applied to the study of atomic structures of matter (statistical physics). This generalization has been most successful in the special case in which the symmetry group is amenable, which means that there exist bounded subsets of the group that have small surface area relative to volume. This condition allows researchers to study dynamical systems by first restricting the dynamics to a finite or bounded subset of the symmetry group and then consider the limiting behavior as the subset grows in size to encompass the group. The point is that amenability implies surface tension effects are negligible in the large-scale limit. 

 

There are many non-amenable groups for which it would be desirable to have comparable results. For example, groups that correspond geometrically to infinite trees, groups that encode the space of all lattices in Euclidean space and groups with hyperbolic features. Such groups arise naturally in connection with problems in geometry, number theory and combinatorics. The overall goal of this project is to extend results from classical dynamics to the non-amenable group setting. 

 

Intellectual Merit: The project has resulted in a number of advances in the areas of sofic entropy theory (a generalization of classical entropy theory to a broad class of groups containing many non-amenable groups), pointwise ergodic theorems for geometrically defined groups, stationary actions of groups, weak equivalence of actions, invariant random subgroups, and importing tools from geometric group theory to the study of measured equivalence relations. Highlights include a counterexample to the Weak Pinsker problem, a solution to the Gaboriau-Lyons problem for positive entropy actions, a lower bound for the Cheeger constant of free groups acting on high dimensional hyperbolic spaces and a new simpler proof of the ergodic theorem for rank 1 simple Lie groups (with Amos Nevo). These advances have been published in high quality journals such as Duke J. Math, GAFA, and Ann. Sci. Ec. Norm. Super. The results have been presented at the ICM and in five invited lecture series, including the Minerva Lectures at Princeton.

 

Broader Impacts: Sofic entropy theory has developed rapidly, which can make it difficult for researchers outside the field to get a handle on it. For this project, the PI wrote a brief gentle introduction (for the ICM) and a detailed survey article and gave several lecture series both in the US and abroad. This project supported the training of one undergraduate student (who has recently entered graduate school at Princeton) and two graduate students. The PI also mentored a postdoctoral fellow (Peter Burton) and co-organized 4 conferences in the US and Canada. The PI is an editor for the Journal of Modern Dynamics.
